body:
NOTE: this PR is in "work in progress" state (to verify that this solution helps with tree-shaking) and is missing tests and detailed docs.

This commit updates the logic that calculates `useFactory` function arguments to avoid relying on `instanceof`
checks (thus always retaining symbols) and relies on specific flags that DI decorators contain.

Closes #40143.

## PR Type

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

title: refactor(compiler-cli): return symbols for each input/output binding on an attribute

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
These commits ensure that the template type checker returns symbols for
all inputs and outputs if a template attribute binds to more than one.

This does not yet address two way bindings, but rather the case where
a given input might be bound to multiple directives.

title: feat(language-service): Initial implementation of find rename locations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
Commit 1:
This commit lays the groundwork for potentially providing rename
locations from the Ivy native LS. The approach is very similar to what
was done with the feature to find references. One difference, however,
is that we did not require the references to be fully "correct". That
is, the exact text spans did not matter so much, as long as we provide a
location that logically includes the referenced item.

An example of a necessary difference between rename locations and references is
directives. The entire element in the template is a "reference" of the
directive's class. However, it's not a valid location to be renamed. The
same goes for aliased inputs/outputs. The locations in the template
directly map to the class property, which is correct for references, but
would not be correct for rename locations, which should instead map to
the string node fo the alias.

As an initial approach to address the aforementioned issues with rename
locations, we check that all the rename location nodes have the same text. If
_any_ node has text that differs from the request, we do not return any
rename locations. This works as a way to prevent renames that could
break the the program by missing some required nodes in the rename action, but
allowing other nodes to be renamed.

Commit 2:
Implement `getRenameInfo`

The `getRenameInfo` action is used by consumers to

1. Determine if a location is a candidate for renames
2. Determine what text to use as the starting point for the rename

This implementation makes use of the existing `findRenameLocations` and
uses those results to determine if the given position can be renamed.

# 📚 Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description A snapshot and description for [the lifecycle hooks example](https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#sequence-and-frequency-of-all-lifecycle-events) doesn't match to an actual behavior. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#sequence-and-frequency-of-all-lifecycle-events ### Reproduction Steps** 1. Go to https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#sequence-and-frequency-of-all-lifecycle-events 2. Run the corresponding example in [Stackblitz](https://angular.io/generated/live-examples/lifecycle-hooks/stackblitz.html) 3. In the live example click > the Create... button and then the Destroy... button. 4. Compare a log message sequence in the live example with the one in the docs. ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** **Actual**: a snapshot and description for [the lifecycle hooks example](https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#sequence-and-frequency-of-all-lifecycle-events) doesn't match to an actual behavior. **Expected**: a snapshot and description for [the lifecycle hooks example](https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#sequence-and-frequency-of-all-lifecycle-events) matches to an actual behavior. ## 📷Screenshot ### In the docs ![peek-a-boo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13061803/102275928-2ddad780-3f37-11eb-93c1-f87168262f2e.png) ### Actual behavior ![ang_lifecycle](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13061803/102276092-65498400-3f37-11eb-9538-15dbe069a11b.png) ## 🔥 Exception or Error

title: feat(compiler-cli): expose function to allow short-circuiting of linking

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
The linker is implemented using a Babel transform such that Babel needs
to parse and walk a source file to find the declarations that need to be
compiled. If it can be determined that a source file is known not to
contain any declarations the parsing and walking can be skipped as a
performance improvement. This commit adds an exposed function for tools
that integrate the linker to use to allow short-circuiting of the linker
transform.

title: Xss fix

labels.name: action: merge
labels.description: PR author is ready for this to merge

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: target: lts
labels.description: This PR is targeting a version currently in long-term support

labels.name: target: patch
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next patch release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
Escape the content of the strings so that it can be safely inserted into a comment node.

The issue is that HTML does not specify any way to escape comment end text inside the comment. `<!-- The way you close a comment is with "-->". -->`. Above the `"-->"` is meant to be text not an end to the comment. This can be created programmatically through DOM APIs.

```
div.innerHTML = div.innerHTML
```
One would expect that the above code would be safe to do, but it turns out that because comment text is not escaped, the comment may contain text which will prematurely close the comment opening up the application for XSS attack. (In SSR we programmatically create comment nodes which may contain such text and expect them to be safe.)

This function escapes the comment text by looking for the closing char sequence `-->` and replace it with `-_-_>` where the `_` is a zero width space `\u200B`. The result is that if a comment contains `-->` text it will render normally but it will not cause the HTML parser to close the comment.

title: Using `{{` and `}}` in strings in templates breaks the compiler

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package I believe this is caused by incorrect lexer grammars in `@angular/compiler`. ### Is this a regression? Not that I'm aware of. ### Description Using `{{ ... }}` inside a string inside a template binding throws compile errors, complaining that it cannot parse the input. For example: ```html

{{ 'This is a string literal which breaks the angular compiler... {{ }} <-------- ' }}

``` This shouldn't be the case. Strings should be by-definition any characters, and shouldn't stop the app from compiling correctly. In our use-case, we have a custom i18n solution that uses that syntax for variable replacement within localized strings, and without this fixed, we have to define those strings as class properties in the component's class file instead. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-string-brace-bug?file=src/app/app.component.html ## 🔥 Exception or Error 
Error: src/app/app.component.html:1:1 - error NG5002: Parser Error: Unexpected token Lexer Error: Unterminated quote at column 16 in expression [ "Hello {{ test ] at column 17 in [{{ "Hello {{ test }}!" }} ] in /PATH/TO/PROJECTS/test/src/app/app.component.html@0:0
## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 11.1.0-next.2
Node: 12.15.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.1.0-next.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router, service-worker
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1100.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1101.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/core            11.1.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.1.0-next.2
@angular/fire                   6.1.4
@schematics/angular             11.1.0-next.2
@schematics/update              0.1101.0-next.2
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.1.2
**Anything else relevant?** I don't think so.

N/A

title: ci: `test_win` CI job is flaky due to `bazelbuild/rules_nodejs` linker

labels.name: comp: build & ci
labels.description: Issue related to the Angular team's *own* build/CI tooling

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
Since recently(?) the `test_win` CI job has been flaking (see below for details on the errors). (Initially reported by @petebacondarwin [here][1].) The errors are thrown in the `bazelbuild/rules_nodejs` [linker][2] and seem to be caused by race conditions between several linker instances running in parallel and operating on the same `node_modules/` directory. (As pointed out by @petebacondarwin, these were potentially introduced by bazelbuild/rules_nodejs@2979fad6579641f2b28f16702812437ae361c40b - fyi @devversion) ## I looked at a few recent CI failures and summarize some observations here in case they mean something to someone more familiar with Bazel's and `bazelbuild/rules_nodejs`'s internals :grin: - I looked at the the following failing CI jobs (54 total errors): [881590], [881841], [881877], [881927], [881958], [881987], [882096], [882116], [882203] - The errors seem to involve the `@angular/upgrade` package much more often than other packages. (In the inspected errors, 52 out of 54 were about the `@angular/upgrade` package. The remaining two involved `@angular/compiler-cli` and `@angular/localize`.) Not sure if it is related, but `@angular/upgrade` is also the last Angular package alphabetically. - The errors appear much more often in the `//packages/compiler-cli/ngcc/test:integration` target (31 out of 54 errors). ## Below is a summary of the errors organized in two different ways:
Per Bazel test target (Click to expand) -
//packages/compiler-cli/ngcc/test:integration - shard 1 of 4 (ERRORS: 9) - [881927], [881987]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade__linker_tmp' -> 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [882096]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rmdir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [881927]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rmdir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade\src' - [881877], [882116]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [882116]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade\src' - [881841], [881987]: > [link_node_modules.js] An error has been reported: Error: File does not exist, but is listed as directory entry: @angular\upgrade\src > at C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:85:23 > at Generator.next () > at fulfilled (C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:5:58) Error: File does not exist, but is listed as directory entry: @angular\upgrade\src > at C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:85:23 > at Generator.next () > at fulfilled (C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:5:58)
-
//packages/compiler-cli/ngcc/test:integration - shard 2 of 4 (ERRORS: 7) - [881958]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\localize__linker_tmp' -> 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\localize' - [881590], [881877], [881958], [882203]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade__linker_tmp' -> 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [881877]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [881841]: > [link_node_modules.js] An error has been reported: Error: File does not exist, but is listed as directory entry: @angular\upgrade\src > at C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:85:23 > at Generator.next () > at fulfilled (C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:5:58) Error: File does not exist, but is listed as directory entry: @angular\upgrade\src > at C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:85:23 > at Generator.next () > at fulfilled (C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\build_bazel_rules_nodejs\internal\linker\index.js:5:58)
-
//packages/compiler-cli/ngcc/test:integration - shard 3 of 4 (ERRORS: 11) - [881590], [881841], [881927], [882096], [882116], [882203]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade__linker_tmp' -> 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [881987], [882203]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade' - [881590], [881841], [881927]: > [link_node_modules.js] Error: ENOTEMPTY: directory not empty, rmdir 'C:\users\circleci\_bazel_circleci\u4uoan2j\external\npm\node_modules\@angular\upgrade'

title: $localize tagged template fails in library production build (ViewEngine)

labels.name: P5
labels.description: Very low-priority issue for consideration

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler or @angular/compiler-cli (guessing) ### Is this a regression? Unlikely. ### Description Adding the `@angular/localize/init` import to the library entry file enables the usage of `$localize` to translate the text in TypeScript source code. The build succeeds, unless the `$localize` is used in the providers: ```TS providers: [{ provide: 'example', useValue: $localize`Translated` }], ``` ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction - checkout: https://github.com/klemenoslaj/library-localize-failure - install dependencies (yarn) - execute `ng build library --prod` > NOTE: if we execute `ng build library` (Ivy) the error will not be thrown ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

ERROR: /projects/library/src/lib/library.module.ts:4:1: Error encountered in metadata generated for exported symbol 'LibraryModule': 
 /projects/library/src/lib/library.module.ts:7:47: Metadata collected contains an error that will be reported at runtime: Tagged template expressions are not supported in metadata.
  {"__symbolic":"error","message":"Tagged template expressions are not supported in metadata","line":6,"character":46}
An unhandled exception occurred: /projects/library/src/lib/library.module.ts:4:1: Error encountered in metadata generated for exported symbol 'LibraryModule': 
 /projects/library/src/lib/library.module.ts:7:47: Metadata collected contains an error that will be reported at runtime: Tagged template expressions are not supported in metadata.
  {"__symbolic":"error","message":"Tagged template expressions are not supported in metadata","line":6,"character":46}
See "/private/var/folders/6z/77kchyrx2wz7898g96g0jxf0vwwy9k/T/ng-5deZ0E/angular-errors.log" for further details.
## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 11.0.4
Node: 14.15.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.0.4
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... localize, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

---------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/core            11.0.4
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.0.4

title: feat(compiler-cli): JIT compilation of component declarations

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
The `ɵɵngDeclareComponent` calls are designed to be translated to fully
AOT compiled code during a build transform, but in cases this is not
done it is still possible to compile the declaration object in the
browser using the JIT compiler. This commit adds a runtime
implementation of `ɵɵngDeclareComponent` which invokes the JIT compiler
using the declaration object, such that a compiled component definition
is made available to the Ivy runtime.

title: fix(core): set `ngDevMode` to `false` when calling `enableProdMode()`

labels.name: action: merge
labels.description: PR author is ready for this to merge

labels.name: action: time-zone
labels.description: The author of this PR is in a different time zone. Try to minimize roundtrips.

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: target: lts
labels.description: This PR is targeting a version currently in long-term support

labels.name: target: patch
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next patch release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
Currently, the global `ngDevMode` is set to false when using the Angular CLI `optimization` option. This option sets the globals via terser using the Compiler CLI private tooling API https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d39d64c15dcba74aa673cacfc1365bd35a1d4f95/packages/compiler-cli/src/tooling.ts#L25-L34.

It is not documented that users not using the Angular CLI or using Angular Universal without `optimization` need to manually set to `false` as otherwise they will be vulnerable to XHR attacks.

The `ngDevMode` description also mentions that calling `enableProdMode` will set the value to `false`.
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4610093c87975b6355f31a9c849351129908783a/packages/core/src/util/ng_dev_mode.ts#L22 which is currently not the case.

Closes #37644

title: fix(core): take @Host into account while processing `useFactory` arguments

labels.name: comp: build & ci
labels.description: Issue related to the Angular team's *own* build/CI tooling

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: target: patch
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next patch release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
DI provider can be defined via `useFactory` function, which may have arguments configured via `deps` array.
The `deps` array may contain DI flags represented by DI decorators (such as `@Self`, `@SkipSelf`, etc). Prior to this
commit, having the `@Host` decorator in `deps` array resulted in runtime error in Ivy. The problem was that the `@Host`
decorator was not taken into account while `useFactory` argument list was constructed, the `@Host` decorator was
treated as a token that should be looked up.

This commit updates the logic which prepares `useFactory` arguments to recognize the `@Host` decorator.


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

title: fix(core): Call `onDestroy` in production mode as well

labels.name: action: merge
labels.description: PR author is ready for this to merge

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: target: patch
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next patch release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
PR #39876 introduced an error where the `onDestroy` of `ComponentRef` would only get called if `ngDevMode` was set to true. This was because in dev mode we would freeze `TCleanup` to verify that no more static cleanup would get added to `TCleanup` array. This ensured that `TCleanup` was always present in dev mode. In production the `TCleanup` would get created only when needed. The resulting cleanup code was incorrectly indented and would only run if `TCleanup` was present causing this issue.

Fix #40105

title: refactor(compiler-cli): emit `forwardRef` invocation for forward type references

labels.name: action: merge
labels.description: PR author is ready for this to merge

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: refactoring
labels.description: Issue that involves refactoring or code-cleanup

labels.name: target: minor
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next minor release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
The types of directives and pipes that are used in a component's
template may be emitted into the partial declaration wrapped inside a
closure, which is needed when the type is declared later in the module.
This poses a problem for JIT compilation of partial declarations, as
this closure is indistinguishable from a class reference itself. To mark
the forward reference function as such, this commit changes the partial
declaration codegen to emit a `forwardRef` invocation wrapped around
the closure, which ensures that the closure is properly tagged as a
forward reference. This allows the forward reference to be treated as
such during JIT compilation.

title: fix(core): ensure sanitizer works if DOMParser return null body

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

labels.name: security
labels.description: Issue related to security

labels.name: target: patch
labels.description: This PR is targeted for the next patch release

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
In some browsers, notably a mobile version of webkit on iPad, the
result of calling `DOMParser.parseFromString()` returns a document
whose `body` property is null until the next tick of the browser.
Since this is of no use to us for sanitization, we now fall back to the
"inert document" strategy for this case.

Fixes #39834

title: Angular http client not working with translation on in IOS chrome browser

labels.name: iOS
labels.description: Issue related to Apple's iOS operating system

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Description I have angular project built in angular 10. I am getting issue in calling api from IOS chrome browser when i turn on google translation from browser. If i do not turn on translation it is giving me correct response for API However when i turn on translation i am getting this error. `InvalidAccessError The object does not support the operation or argument` Error is happening only when i do translation from browser if i do translation from settings in Iphone the it is working fine. and it is also working fine in all browsers in laptop. If use javascript fetch function instead of angular HttpClient then it is working fine with HttpClient request is not even going to server. It is giving error even before sending request. I tried to reproduce same issue in stackblitz but if i create any app on stackblitz than translate button is disabled there. You can see this stackblitz app created by me - https://angular-9-starter-gf561h.stackblitz.io/ ![translate-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67366916/102060311-06411d80-3e18-11eb-9fb1-b4348a5d90e9.jpg) You can see in stackblitz this `trnaslate` option in dislabled. but it is enabled in my local app. And once i click on that button than httpClient stops working To Regenerate issue 1) Install latest angular app 2) add any httpClient service in app 3) run app and open in. Iphone chrome 4) Api call will stop working after clicking on translate button in IOS chrome. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction ## 🔥 Exception or Error
## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



10.0.0
**Anything else relevant?**
